title: Mozambique: World Bank Praises Financial Inclusion Efforts
text:
Mozambique: District Administrator Guilty of Embezzlement 
Lundell argued that Africa still has a long way to go before reaching full levels of financial inclusion, since currently “three out of every four adults do not have bank accounts - that is, they have no access to a place where they can keep their money safely”. 
He argued that it is crucial to increase support for small and medium companies, since these are one of the main methods of guaranteeing financial inclusion - yet these companies often have no access to credit. 
Lundell said there are literally millions of micro, small and medium companies in Africa that are denied the funding that would help them to develop, increase their productive capacity and thus help drive economic and social growth. 
For his part, the governor of the Bank of Mozambique, Ernesto Gove, argued that, in order to ensure financial inclusion, it is crucial to expand banking services to the more remote parts of the country. 
The commercial banks have been dragging their feet, and despite pressure from the central bank, still concentrate the vast bulk of their services in the main cities. Less than half of Mozambique's 141 districts are served by branches of the commercial banks. 
Gove said there are three essential bases for financial inclusion - first, the expansion of points of access to banking services and products, second, an increase in the number of users of banking services, and finally an improved level of knowledge about the country's banking system. 
He claimed that a strengthening of the financial infrastructures could contribute significantly to poverty reduction. 
The one day consultation seeks to identify the main obstacles to insurance services and capital markets, and to electronic banking services. It will also look at the main priorities for improving the financial education and protection of Mozambican consumers. Mozambique
